REDWATER ISD EARNS 2020 TAEA DISTRICT OF DISTINCTION

Over 1,000 districts state-wide were eligible to apply for the Texas Art Education Association Visual Arts Award. Redwater ISD was one of only 42 districts to meet the high standards and will receive the outstanding honor indicating they are in the top 4 percent of districts in the state. The TAEA Administration and Supervision Division as sponsor, recognizes districts with outstanding leadership in promoting the arts in their district and community. We want to award districts that are actively participating members in TAEA and beyond TAEA sponsored events. This year's recipients exemplify a visual arts district of distinction.

CONGRATULATIONS to Redwater ISD and its visual arts students and instrutors. Instructors include: Carrie Slay - high school art Tabitha Houchens - high school and junior high photography, Stacie Norton - junior high and middle school art, and Stacy Deaton - elementary art.

P-EBT UPDATE:
P-EBT provides a one-time benefit of up to $285 per eligible child that families can use to purchase
food. Eligible families that have children 5-18 years old and received SNAP benefits for March have
already received P-EBT benefits. All other eligible families must apply to receive P-EBT benefits.
Thousands of families across Texas have applied for the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT)
program. However, there are still many more students that are eligible for this program. On average,
only 70% of eligible families in Texas have applied for P-EBT. The deadline to apply for P-EBT is
Tuesday, June 30.

Families that need help filling out the P-EBT application can call the P-EBT call center at 833-
613-6220 Monday through Friday, 8:00 am – 6:00 pm.

Do you have questions about P-EBT?
For more information, please visit http://hhs.texas.gov/pebt (English) or http://hhs.texas.gov/es/pebt
(Spanish) or contact the P-EBT Call Center at 833-613-6220 Monday through Friday, 8:00 am – 6:00 pm.

Artwork by Zoe Gonzalez, a third-grade student at Redwater Elementary School, has been selected for display in the State Capitol and the Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum in March as part of the Texas Art Education Association Youth Art Month Exhibit.

Only students from 61 school districts across the state will receive this prestigious honor.

Zoe's artwork, "Baby Bluebonnet," features her natural artistic talent. “Zoe created a grazing mare from her handprint made with liquid tempera, and she used dry tempera along with various colors of tissue paper to add dimension to her landscape," says Stacy Deaton, Fine Arts teacher at Redwater Elementary School.

post_text: Eli Bates, a seventh grader at Redwater Junior High, has been selected as the February Student of the Month. Eli exhibits kindness and compassion each day as he chooses to hold the door open for all students to pass through. Even on cold and rainy days when everyone is rushing to get in out of the weather, he stands, seemingly oblivious to the elements, while his classmates come and go. His courtesy has not been a detriment to his attendance record as Eli has not had a single tardy this school year! In addition, Eli’s teachers report that he is a dedicated student in both the traditional classroom setting as well as elective classes. His work ethic and his willingness to help and offer support to others carries through in all areas. Redwater Junior High is pleased to recognize Eli Bates as the February Student of the Month. #RJH #rwdragonproud

In "Chopped" five contestants have five minutes to write a story with five unrelated words that must be in included in the story. Then the students read their stories to the class which acts as judges to decide two stories which are not their favorites and "chops" them from the winners. The three remaining contestants are voted on the second time for the best story. The top three contestants win candy. Pictured are Mrs. Spiropoulus and the winner from her third period class. #RJH

post_text: Redwater Junior High continues to be proud of our students as they demonstrate what it means to care for each other. A seventh grader, Gracie Duncan, revealed her outstanding character as she stepped up to help out a preschool student who came into the cafetorium very upset because of a skinned knee, and who did not want any medical attention. Despite this being one of the first times Gracie was in the cafetorium for breakfast, she immediately went to assist the young student. She was able to, not only help calm him down, but she escorted him to his campus for further assistance. We are delighted in this outstanding example of “citizenship” carried out by Gracie. The faculty and staff of Redwater Junior High are very pleased to recognize Gracie Duncan as the November Student of the Month. #RJH #rwdragonproud

post_text: Tanner Harrison, an eighth grader at Redwater Junior High, has been selected as the first recipient of the school year for the Redwater Junior High Student of the Month. Tanner noticed a distressed preschooler, who wanted to remain on the bus due to the rain. Tanner used the bus driver’s umbrella to walk the student to class, where all was well and both were dry and stress-free. Tanner proves that there are no small acts, only acts of kindness that make a huge difference in the recipient’s life. The faculty and staff at Redwater Junior High are proud of Tanner for being an example to all. #rwdragonproud #RJH

THANK YOU to Texarkana Walmart #2123 for supporting public education!

This morning, Walmart store manager, George Wood, awarded Redwater ISD with a $1,000 grant from the Walmart Community Grant Fund.

Redwater ISD superintendent Dr. Kelly Burns, junior high principal Kim Cody and junior high students accepted the award on the district’s behalf at an award ceremony hosted by the store. RISD plans to use this grant to improve our student health and safety programs.

“We want to extend a heartfelt thank you to Walmart for giving back to your communities and supporting our students,” Burns said.
